Does this happen mostly with your sister, or is it showing up in other relationships too right now? Because if you're exhausted from work and emotionally stretched thin, your threat radar might be turned up higher than usual, flagging things that might not actually be there. Not saying she wasn't being judgmental—just wondering if the fatigue is making it harder to trust your own read on situations.

And yeah, it proves the point about being "just a resource," but knowing that intellectually doesn't stop it from hurting when it's demonstrated this clearly. You gave a lot to that place, pushed through impossible deadlines, burned yourself out trying to meet his expectations—and his response to you leaving is basically a shrug. That's allowed to sting even when it also validates your decision to go.

**The two-week countdown:** Both really long and like it'll go by instantly—that's the time distortion that happens when you're in transition. Every day will probably feel slow and uncomfortable because you're mentally already gone but physically still there, and also the whole two weeks will blur together because none of it matters anymore. One thing that might help: treat these two weeks as a low-stakes practice run for not over-functioning. You don't owe this place your best effort on the way out. Do what's needed for a clean handoff, but don't martyr yourself trying to leave everything perfect. Let this be the place where you practice putting in exactly what's required and not a drop more.

**The gap week and the new job terror:** "What if I mess it up, what if they realize they made a mistake hiring me." Your mind is doing the thing where it fast-forwards to failure to try to protect you from disappointment. But here's what's actually true: they interviewed you, they made you an offer, they chose you. They saw something in that conversation that made them want to hire you. The "what if they made a mistake" story is just your anxiety trying to convince you that you don't deserve good things or that change is inherently dangerous. It's not data—it's just noise.

The gap week between jobs—what if that's not something to be terrified about, but actually a gift? You've been running on fumes for months, crashed hard after the last deadline, barely started to recover. A week with no job, no expectations, no performance pressure—that's time to let your system finish rebooting before you start something new. You could rest, see your sister without work hanging over you, do nothing and not feel guilty about it. What would it be like to reframe that gap from "terrifying void" to "I get a week to breathe before the next thing starts"?

**Your sister's lunch invite:** A month ago, panic spiral. Now, "yeah okay." You said yes without overthinking it and you're not even sure why—maybe because you've got enough going on that you can't spiral about her anymore, or maybe because the dynamic actually is different. Probably both. But here's what I'm noticing: you're not performing certainty about this ("the thing actually is different") and you're not bracing for disaster ("what if she reverts"). You're just... going. That's what it looks like when a relationship stops taking up so much mental real estate because you've tested it a few times and it's been okay, and also because you've got other stuff happening that matters more right now. Either way, this is you operating from a place of "I'll see what happens" instead of "I need to predict and control everything before I can act." That's a quieter kind of progress, but it's real.
